doc.title: China Jinmao (0817.HK)
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS/China Jinmao 0817.HK 1H25 broadly inline salesmargin recovery underpinned by upbeat land investment and asset optimizati_2025-08-29

processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS
processing_metadata.input_relative_path: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS

passages.text: Echoing our preview, China Jinmao reported broadly inline 1H core profit (before PCS distribution) up \(2\%\) yoy, under mixed impact of 1) solid topline growth at \(+14\%\) yoy driven by stronger DP revenue booking, 2) inline GPM at flatish yoy, with 1pp DP margin enhancement being offset by weakened recurring business GPMs, 3) optimized SG&A expenses due to effective organization streamlining, and 4) higher- than- expected tax expenses. Jinmao declared HK\$0.03 DPS in 1H (flatish yoy and implying a \(2\%\) yield on Aug- 29 closing price) and management vowed to adhere to a \(40\%\) payout of core profit going forward, implying average \(5\%\) yield in 2025E- 27E.

Key management guidance: 1) management is confident to achieve Rmb110bn contract sales for FY25, implying \(+12\%\) yoy and c. \(55\%\) sell- through against its c.Rmb200bn saleable resources planned for the year; 2) management strives to continue active land acquisition, budgeting c.Rmb20bn- 30bn attributable land investment p.a. in upcoming years (incl. another c.Rmb10bn for 2H25 following Rmb22bn spent in the 1H); 3) management targets to de- stock \(35\%\) and \(80\%\) of its aged inventory by end- 25 and end- 27 via various asset revitalization channels (e.g. leveraging government buy- backs, city operations, bulk asset transactions, etc.); 4) management expects DP margin to recover in FY26 onwards, with rising contribution from higher- profitability investments since FY24 (e.g. 1H25 new land acquisitions carry c. \(20\%\) project- level GPM, vs. \(11\%\) DP booking GPM in FY24); 5) in longer- run, management aims to achieve healthy balance sheet and asset structure by FY27 and expects more quality and sustainable growth trajectory in FY28- 30.

Looking forward, we are constructive on Jinmao's contract sales outlook, and forecast Rmb116bn for 25E (+18% yoy, implying 2H25E at \(+16\%\) yoy) and average \(9\%\) p.a. growth in 26E- 27E, ahead of peers and average \(1\%\) above prior GSe; we expect this to be supported by 1) quality land bank which carries Rmb320bn total saleable resources by 1H25, \(88\% /62\%\) of which are located in Tier- 1/2cities/Jimao's identified Top- 10 cities (9pp and 3pp above end- 24 levels) and 2f intensified efforts for aged inventory de- stocking. We also see strengthened margin recovery visibility: in N- T, we still estimate low- teen %

DP GPM level for 25E- 26E, considering the share of its incremental land bank might not yet be able to lift its overall GPM, coupled with its planned increase in active sales campaign to clean up aged inventory; that said, we expect more material boost from recent land acquisitions in 27E onwards to potentially mid- teen % level booking GPM.

What we revised: post 1H results, we fine- tune our 2025E- 27E underlying earnings by \(0\%\) to \(+3\%\) to mainly reflect: 1) \(4\%\) higher topline mainly on higher DP booking revenue driven by enhanced construction efficiency and intensified aged inventory de- stocking, 2) average 0.1pp higher GPM driven by increased DP booking margin recovery visibility and 0.1pp lower SG&A expense against revenue ratio riding on ongoing organizational streaming, 3) refreshed net interest expenses baking in market interest rates and Jinmao's 1H net borrowing cost trends, and 4) updated effective tax rate assumptions. Our end- 25E NAV estimate remains largely unchanged. Maintain Buy rating with 12m TP of HK\$1.9 (unchanged), still based on a \(10\%\) discount to end- 25E NAV. Jinmao trades at a \(33\%\) discount to end- 25E NAV, 0.5X 2025E P/B and \(3\%\) dividend yield vs. our offshore developer coverage averages of \(28\%\) , 0.5X and \(2\%\) yield respectively.

Positives: 1) contract sales outperformance with a solid \(20\%\) yoy growth in 1H25 (vs. \(- 14\%\) yoy by Top- 10 developers per CRIC); amongst, \(75\%\) took place in Jinmao's Top- 10 cities (vs. \(61\%\) in FY24) and residential ASP rose to Rmb26k/sqm (+18% above FY24 level), strengthening booking revenue and margin outlook in upcoming years; mgmt. also noted that multiple projects achieved solid sell- through rates coupled with price premium against initially set ASP, showcasing Jinmao's product attractiveness, strong brand name and seasoned marketing ability; 2) accelerated landbanking pace with competitive margin profile: Jinmao's 1H25 16 new land acquisitions accounted for over \(90\%\) of its presales by value (vs. average \(25\%\) in FY22- 24). Correspondingly, by end- 1H25, Jinmao had GFA26.8mn sqm property development landbank carrying c.Rmb320bn saleable resources (+14% from end- 24 level); mgmt. also estimated c. \(20\%\) project- level GPMs for 1H25 new land acquisitions (vs. FY24/1H25 DP booking of \(11\% /12\%\) ); 3) solid topline growth at \(+14\%\) , mainly supported by stronger DP booking revenue \(+17\%\) yoy and accelerated property management revenue (+20% yoy, riding on \(\frac{1}{2} \%\) yoy management scale ramp- up and VAS diversification); 4) DP GPM improvement by 1pp yoy to \(12\%\) , mainly due to the booking of high- margin projects in Beijing, Shanghai and Xi'an during 1H; 5) optimized SG&A expenses due to effective organization streamlining (esp. disbanding the five major regions and adjusting them into a two- tiered management system of "headquarters - regional companies"); 6) new low financing cost of \(2.96\%\) (vs. \(4.2\% /3.8\%\) at 1H24/end- 24) with optimized debt structure, incl. FX debt exposure lowering to \(21\%\) from \(25\%\) at end- 24 and the share of bank loan rising to \(41\%\) from \(22\%\) at end- 24.

Negatives: 1) weaker- than- expected recurring revenue, with consolidated rental income at \(- 5\%\) yoy and \(- 3\%\) hoh, as well as declining hotel revenue at \(- 12\%\) yoy and \(- 5\%\) hoh due to dim consumer confidence, macroeconomic adversities and asset disposal (i.e. Hilton Sanya in 2H24); hotel GPM also underperformed at - 9pp yoy; 2) 2pp
yoy property management GPM deterioration; 3) higher-than-expected effective tax rate.

Jinmao is a subsidiary of state- owned Sinochem Corporation, ranked 13rd on the 2023 Chinese property developers list (in terms of sales, ranked by CRIC). We have a Buy rating on Jinmao driven by: 1) its healthy balance sheet (sits in the green camp under 3RL) with high quality land banks (including those from city operation projects) leveraged on the parent SOE Sinochem group; and 2) increasing revenue contribution from recurring rental/property management segments etc., supporting gradual earnings recovery post the dip in 2022- 23. Jinmao remains undervalued vs. other SOE developers and its historical trading range.

Key risks: Delays in land sales or unexpected austerity measures to cap land sale prices would result in earnings volatility and below- expectation margins; given its high land cost in high- tier cities, execution slippages in expansion may compress future margin prospects and lead to balance sheet deterioration; weak execution of its recurring business (property leasing, hotel and property management) that potentially leads to topline and earnings downside and weakening visibility for asset monetization opportunities; diminishing support from parent Sinochem Group.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.
